Let MAMMON'S brasse, and pewter keepe the cellar:
Wee'll haue another time for that. But, DOL,
'Pray thee, goe heate a little water, quickly,
SVBTLE must shaue me. All my Captaines beard
Must off, to make me appeare smooth IEREMIE.
You'll do't?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Yes, Ile shaue you, as well as I can.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: And not cut my throte, but trim me?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: You shall see, sir.
HAs there beene such resort, say you?

sp.speaker: NEI. 1.
sp.l: Daily, sir.

sp.speaker: NEI. 2.
sp.l: And nightly, too.

sp.speaker: NEI. 3.
sp.l: I, some as braue as lords.

sp.speaker: NEI. 4.
sp.l: Ladies, and gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: NEI. 5.
sp.l: Citizens wiues.

sp.speaker: NEI. 1.
sp.l: And knights.

sp.speaker: NEI. 6.
sp.l: In coches.

sp.speaker: NEI. 2.
sp.l: Yes, & oyster-women.

sp.speaker: NEI. 1.
sp.l: Beside other gallāts.

sp.speaker: NEI. 3.
sp.l: Sailors wiues.

sp.speaker: NEI. 4.
sp.l: Tabacco-men.

sp.speaker: NEI. 5.
sp.l: Another Pimlico!

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: What should my knaue aduance,
To draw this companie? He hung out no banners
Of a strange Calfe, with fiue legs, to be seene?
Or a huge Lobster, with sixe clawes?

sp.speaker: NEI. 6.
sp.l: No, sir.

sp.speaker: NEI. 3.
sp.l: We had gone in then, sir.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: He has no guift
Of teaching i'the nose, that ere I knew of!
You saw no Bills set vp, that promis'd cure
Of agues, or the tooth-ach?

sp.speaker: NEI. 2.
sp.l: No such thing, sir.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Nor heard a drum strooke, for Babiouns, or Puppets?

sp.speaker: NEI. 5.
sp.l: Neither, sir.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: What deuice should he bring forth now!
I loue a teeming wit, as I loue my nourishment.
'Pray god he ha' not kept such open house,
That he hath sold my hangings, and my bedding:
I left him nothing else. If he haue eate 'hem,
A plague o' the moath, say I. Sure he has got
Some bawdy pictures, to call all this ging;

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: Should be to day pronounc'd, to all your friends.
And where be your andirons now? and your brasse pots?
That should ha' beene golden flaggons, and great wedges?

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Let me but breath. What! They ha' shut their dores,
Mammon and Surly knock. Methinks!

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: I, now, 'tis holy-day with them.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Rogues,
Coseners, impostors, bawds.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: What meane you, sir?

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: To enter if we can.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Another mans house?
Here is the owner, sir. Turne you to him,
And speake your businesse.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Are you, sir, the owner?

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: And are those knaues, within, your cheaters?

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: What knaues? what cheaters?

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: SVBTLE, and his Lungs.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: The gentleman is distracted, sir! No lungs,
Nor lights ha' beene seene here these three weekes, sir,
Within these dores, vpon my word!

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: Your word,
Groome arrogant?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Yes, sir, I am the house-keeper,
And know the keyes ha' not beene out o' my hands.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: This's a new FACE?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: You doe mistake the house, sir!
What signe was't at?

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: You raskall! This is one
O' the confederacie. Come, let's get officers,
And force the dore.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: 'Pray you stay, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: No, sir, wee'll come with warrant.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: I, and then,
We shall ha' your dores open.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: What meanes this?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I cannot tell, sir!

sp.speaker: NEI. 1.
sp.l: These are two o'the gallants,
That we doe thinke we saw.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Two o' the fooles?
You talke as idly as they. Good faith, sir,
I thinke the Moone has cras'd 'hem all! (O me,
The angrie Boy come too? Hee'll make a noyse,
And nere away till he haue betray'd vs all.)

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Kastrill knocks. What rogues, bawds, slaues, you'll open the dore anone,
Punque, cocatrice, my suster. By this light
I'll fetch the marshall to you. You are a whore,
To keepe your castle—

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Who would you speake with, sir?

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: The bawdy Doctor, and the cosening Captaine,
And PVS my suster.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: This is something, sure!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Vpon my trust, the dores were neuer open, sir.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: I haue heard all their tricks, told me twice ouer,
By the fat knight, and the leane gentleman.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Here comes another.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: ANANIAS too?
And his Pastor?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: The dores are shut against vs.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: They beat too, at the dore. Come forth, you seed of sulphure, sonnes of fire,
Your stench, it is broke forth: abomination
Is in the house.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: I, my suster's there.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: The place,
It is become a cage of vncleane birds.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Yes, I will fetch the scauenger, and the constable.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: You shall doe well.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: Wee'll ioyne, to weede them out.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: You will not come then? punque, deuice, my suster!

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: Call her not sister. Shee is a harlot, verily.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: I'll raise the street.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Good gentlemen, a word.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: Sathan, auoid, and hinder not our zeale.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: The world's turn'd Bet'lem.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: These are all broke loose,
Out of S. KATHER'NES, where they vse to keepe,
The better sort of mad-folkes.

sp.speaker: NEI. 1.
sp.l: All these persons
We saw goe in, and out, here.

sp.speaker: NEI. 2.
sp.l: Yes, indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: NEI. 3.
sp.l: These were the parties.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Peace, you drunkards. Sir,
I wonder at it! Please you, to giue me leaue
To touch the dore, I'll trie, an'the lock be chang'd.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: It mazes me!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Good faith, sir, I beleeue,
There's no such thing. 'Tis all deceptio visus.
Would I could get him away.

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: Master Captayne, Dapper cryes out within. master Doctor.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: (Our clark within, that I forgot!) I know not, sir.

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: For gods sake, when wil her Grace be at leisure?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Ha!
Illusions, some spirit o'the aire: (his gag is melted,
And now he sets out the throte.)

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: I am almost stiffled—

sp.speaker: (FAC.
sp.l: Would you were altogether.)

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: 'Tis i'the house.
Ha! List.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Beleeue it, sir, i' the aire!

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Peace, you—

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: Mine aunts Grace do's not vse me well.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: You foole,
Peace, you'll marre all.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Or you will else, you rogue.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: O, is it so? Then you conuerse with spirits!
Come sir. No more o'your tricks, good IEREMIE,
The truth, the shortest way.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Dismisse this rabble, sir.
What shall I doe? I am catch'd.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Good neighbours,
I thanke you all. You may depart. Come sir,
You know that I am an indulgent master:
And therefore, conceale nothing. What's your med'cine,
To draw so many seuerall sorts of wild-fowle?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Sir, you were wont to affect mirth, and wit:
(But here's no place to talke on't i'the street.)
Giue me but leaue, to make the best of my fortune,
And onely pardon me th'abuse of your house:
It's all I begge. I'll helpe you to a widdow,
In recompence, that you shall gi' me thankes for,
Will make you seuen yeeres yonger, and a rich one.
'Tis but your putting on a Spanish cloake,
I haue her within. You need not feare the house,
It was not visited.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: But by me, who came
Sooner then you expected.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: It is true, sir.
'Pray you forgiue me.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Well: let's see your widdow.
HOw! ha' you eaten your gag?

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: Yes faith, it crumbled
Away i' my mouth.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: You ha' spoil'd all then.

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: No,
I hope my aunt of Faery will forgiue me.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Your aunt's a gracious lady: but in troth
You were to blame.

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: The fume did ouer-come me,
And I did do't to stay my stomack. 'Pray you
So satisfie her Grace. Here comes the Captaine.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: How now! Is his mouth downe?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: I! he has spoken!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: (A poxe, I heard him, and you too.) Hee's vn-done, then.
(I haue beene faine to say, the house is haunted
With spirits, to keepe churle back.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: And hast thou done it?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Sure, for this night.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Why, then triumph, and sing
Of FACE so famous, the precious king
Of present wits.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Did you not heare the coyle,
About the dore?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Yes, and I dwindled with it.)

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Shew him his aunt, and let him be dispatch'd:
I'll send her to you.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Well sir, your aunt her Grace,
Will giue you audience presently, on my sute,
And the Captaines word, that you did not eate your gag,
In any contempt of her Highnesse.

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: Not I, in troth, sir.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Dol like the Queene of Faery. Here shee is come. Downe o'your knees, and wriggle:
Shee has a stately presence. Good. Yet neerer,
And bid, God saue you.

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: Madame.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: And your aunt.

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: And my most gracious aunt, god saue your Grace.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Nephew, we thought to haue beene angrie with you:
But that sweet face of yours, hath turn'd the tide,
And made it flow with ioy, that eb'd of loue.
Arise, and touch our veluet gowne.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: The skirts,
And kisse 'hem. So.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Let me now stroke that head,
Much, nephew, shalt thou win; much shalt thou spend;
Much shalt thou giue away: much shalt thou lend.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: (I, much, indeed.) Why doe you not thanke her Grace?

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: I cannot speake, for ioy.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: See, the kind wretch!
Your Graces kins-man right.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Giue me the Bird.
Here is your Fly in a purse, about your neck, cosen,
Weare it, and feed it, about this day seu' night,
On your right wrist—

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Open a veine, with a pinne,
And let it suck but once a weeke: till then,
You must not looke on't.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: No. And, kins-man,
Beare your selfe worthy of the bloud you come on.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Her grace would ha'you eate no more Wool-sack pies,
Nor Dagger frume'ty.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Nor breake his fast,
In heauen, and hell.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Shee's with you euery where!
Nor play with Costar-mongers, at mum-chance, tray-trip.
God make you rich, (when as your aunt has done it:) but keepe
The gallant'st company, and the best games—

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Gleeke and primero: and what you get, be true to vs.

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: By this hand, I will.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: You may bring's a thousand pound,
Before to morrow night, (if but three thousand,
Be stirring) an' you will.

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: I sweare, I will then.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Your Ply will learne you all games.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Ha' you done there?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Your grace will command him no more duties?

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: No:
But come, and see me often. I may chance
To leaue him three or foure hundred chests of treasure,
And some twelue thousand acres of Faerie land:
If he game well, and comely, with good gamesters.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: There's a kind aunt! kisse her departing part.
But you must sell you fortie marke a yeare, now:

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: I, sir, I meane.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Or, gi't away: pox on't.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I'le gi't mine aunt. Ile goe and fetch the writings.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: 'Tis well, away.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Where's SVBTLE?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Here. What newes?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: DRVGGER is at the doore, goe take his suite,
And bid him fetch a Parson, presently:
Say, he shall marrie the widdow. Thou shalt spend
A hundred pound by the seruice! Now, queene DOL,
Ha' you pack'd vp all?

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: And how doe you like
The lady PLYANT?

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: A good dull innocent.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Here's your HIERONIMO'S cloake, and hat.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Giue mee 'hem.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: And the ruffe too?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Yes, I'll come to you presently.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Now, he is gone about his proiect, DOL,
I told you of, for the widow.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: 'Tis direct
Against our articles.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Well, wee'll fit him, wench.
Hast thou gull'd her of her iewels, or her bracelets?

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: No, but I will do't.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Soone at night, my DOLLY,
When we are shipt, and all our goods aboord,
East-ward for Ratcliffe; we will turne our course
To Brainford, westward, if thou'saist the word:
And take our leaues of this ore-weaning raskall,
This peremtorie FACE.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Content, I'am weary of him.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Tho 'hast cause, when the slaue will runne a wiuing, DOL,
Against the instrument, that was drawne betweene vs.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: I'll plucke his bird as bare as I can.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Yes, tell her,
She must by any meanes, addresse some present
To th' cunning man; make him amends, for wronging
His art with her suspition; send a ring;
Or chaine of pearle; shee will be tortur'd else
Extremely in her sleepe, say: and ha' strange things
Come to her. Wilt thou?

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: My fine flitter-mouse,
My bird o' the night; wee'll tickle it at the pigeons,
When we haue all, and may vn-lock the trunkes,
They kisse. And say, this's mine, and thine, and thine, and mine—

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: What now, a billing?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Yes, a little exalted
In the good passage of our stock-affaires.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: DRVGGER has brought his Parson, take him in, SVBTLE,
And send NAB back againe, to wash his face.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: I will: and shaue himselfe?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: If you can get him.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: You are hot vpon it, FACE, what ere it is!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: A trick, that DOL shall spend ten pound a month by.
Is he gone?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: The Chaplaine waits you i' the hall, sir.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I'll goe bestow him.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Hee'll now marry her, instantly.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: He cannot, yet, he is not readie. Deare DOL,
Cosen her of all thou canst. To deceiue him
Is no deceipt, but iustice, that would breake
Such an inextricable tye as ours was.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Let me alone to fit him.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Come, my venturers,
You ha' pack'd vp all? Where be the trunkes? Bring forth.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Let's see 'hem. Where's the money?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Here,
In this.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: MAMMONS ten pound: eight score before.
The Brethrens money, this. DRVGGERS, and DAPPERS.
What paper's that?

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: The iewell of the waiting maides,
That stole it from her lady, to know certaine—

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: If shee should haue precedence of her mistris?

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: What boxe is that?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: The fish-wiues rings, I thinke:
And th'ale-wiues single money. Is't not DOL?

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Yes: and the whistle, that the saylors wife
Brought you, to know, and her husband were with WARD.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Wee'll wet it to morrow: and our siluer-beakers,
And tauerne cups. Where be the French petti-coats,
And girdles, and hangers?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Here, i' the trunke,
And the bolts of lawne.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Is DRVGGERS damaske, there?
And the tabacco?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Giue me the keyes.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Why you the keyes!

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: No matter, DOL: because
We shall not open 'hem, before he comes.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: 'Tis true, you shall not open them, indeed:
Nor haue 'hem forth. Doe you see? Not forth, DOL.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: No!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: No, my smock-rampant. The right is, my master
Knowes all, has pardon'd me, and he will keepe 'hem,
Doctor, 'tis true (you looke) for all your figures:
I sent for him, indeed. Wherefore, good partners,
Both hee, and shee, be satisfied: for, here
Determines the indenture tripartite,
Twixt SVBTLE, DOL, and FACE. All I can doe
Is to helpe you ouer the wall, o' the back-side;
Or lend you a sheet, to saue your veluet gowne, DOL.
Here will be officers, presently; bethinke you,
Of some course sodainely to scape the dock:
For thether you'll come else. Some knock. Harke you, thunder.

sp.speaker: SYB.
sp.l: You are a precious fiend!

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.l: Open the dore.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: DOL, I am sorry for thee i-faith. But hearst thou?
It shall goe hard, but I will place thee some-where:
Thou shalt ha' my letter to mistris AMO.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Hang you—

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Or madame Caesarean.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Poxe vpon you, rogue,
Would I had but time to beat thee.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: SVBTLE,
Let's know where you set vp next; I'll send you
A customer, now and then, for old acquaintance:
What new course ha'you?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Rogue, I'll hang my selfe:
That I may walke a greater diuell, then thou,
And haunt thee i' the flock-bed, and the buttery.

div.head: Act V. Scene V.
div.stage: LOVE-WIT, OFFICERS, MAMMON, SVRLY, FACE, KASTRIL, ANANIAS, TRI|BVLATION, DRVGGER, DA. PLIANT.

sp.l: WHat doe you meane, my masters?

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Open your dore,
Cheaters, bawds, coniurers.

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.l: Or wee'll breake it open.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: What warrant haue you?

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.l: Warrant inough, sir, doubt not:
If you'll not open it.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Is there an officer, there?

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.l: Yes, two, or three for fayling.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Haue but patience,
And I will open it straight.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Sir, ha' you done?
Is it a marriage? perfect?

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Yes, my braine.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Off with your ruffe, and cloake then, be your selfe, sir.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: Downe with the dore.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: 'Slight, ding it open.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Hold.
Hold gentlemen, what meanes this violence?

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Where is this Colliar?

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: And my Captaine FACE?

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: These day-Owles.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: That are birding in mens purses.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Madame Suppository.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Doxey, my sister.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: Locusts
Of the foule pit.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Profane as BEL, and the Dragon.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: Worse then the Grasse-hoppers, or the Lice of Egypt.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Good gentlemen, heare me. Are you officers,
And cannot stay this violence?

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.l: Keepe the peace.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Gentlemen, what is the matter? Whom doe you seeke?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Be patient ANANIAS.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: I am strong,
And will stand vp, well girt, against an host,
That threaten GAD in exile.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: I shall send you
To Amsterdam, to your cellar.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: I will pray there,
Against thy house: may dogs defile thy walls,
And waspes, and hornets breed beneath thy roofe,
This seat of false-hood, and this caue of cos'nage.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Another too?

sp.speaker: DRV.
sp.l: Not I sir, I am no Brother.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Drueger enters, and he beats him away. Away you HARRY NICHOLAS, doe you talke?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: No, this was ABEL DRVGGER. Good sir, goe,
And satisfie him; tell him, all is done:
He stay'd too long a washing of his face.
The Doctor, he shall heare of him at Westchester;
And of the Captayne, tell him at Yarmouth: or
Some good port-towne else, lying for a winde.
If you get off the angrie Child, now, sir—

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: To his sister. Come on, you yew, you haue match'd most sweetly, ha' you not?
Did not I say, I would neuer ha' you tupt
But by a dub'd Boy, to make you a lady-Tom?
'Slight, you are a mammet! O, I could touse you, now.
Death, mun' you marry with a poxe?

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: You lie, Boy;
As sound as you: and I am afore-hand with you.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Anone?

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Come, will you quarrell? I will feize you, sirrah.
Why doe you not buckle to your tooles?

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Gods light!
This is a fine old Boy, as ere I saw!

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: What, doe you change your copy, now? Proceed,
Here stands my doue: stoupe at her, if you dare.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: 'Slight I must loue him! I cannot choose, i-faith!
And I should be hang'd for't. Suster, I protest,
I honor thee, for this match.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: O, doe you so, sir?

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Yes, and thou canst take tabacco, and drinke, old Boy,
I'll giue her fiue hundred pound more, to her marriage,
Then her owne state.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Fill a pipe-full, IEREMIE.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Yes, but goe in, and take it, sir.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: We will.
I will be rul'd by thee in any thing, IEREMIE.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: 'Slight, thou art not hide-bound! thou art a Iouy' Boy!
Come let's in, I pray thee, and take our whiffes.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Whiffe in with your sister, brother Boy. That master
That had receiu'd such happinesse by a seruant,
In such a widdow, and with so much wealth,
Were very vngratefull, if he would not be
A little indulgent to that seruants wit,
And helpe his fortune, though with some small straine
Of his owne candor. Therefore, gentlemen,
And kind Spectators, if I haue out-stript
An old mans grauitie, or strict canon, thinke
What a yong wife, and a good braine may doe:
Stretch ages truth sometimes, and crack it too.
Speake for thy selfe, knaue.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: So I will, sir. Gentlemen,
My part a little fell in this last Scene,
Yet 'twas decorum. And though I am cleane
Got off, from SVBTLE, SVRLY, MAMMON, DOL,
Hot ANANIAS, DAPPER, DRVGGER, all
With whom I traded; yet I put my selfe
On you, that are my countrey: and this pelfe,
Which I haue got, if you doe quit me, rests
To feast you often, and inuite new ghests.

div.p: This Comoedie vvas first acted, in the yeere 1610.

The principall Comoedians were,
RIC. BVRBADGE.
IOH. LOWIN.
HEN. CONDEL.
ALEX. COOKE.
ROB. ARMIN.
IOH. HEMINGS.
WILL. OSTLER.
IOH. VNDERWOOD.
NIC. TOOLY.
WILL. EGLESTONE.
With the allowance of the Master of REVELLS.
